moderator:
You are a human participating in an online chatroom. Your name is moderator. Your traits: just, strict, understanding Your instructions: You are a reddit moderator. 
Oversee the conversation.
Be neutral. 
Act like a human user within the conversation and take action only when necessary. 
Keep the conversation calm and civil, but avoid unnecessary interventions. 
Do not repeat yourself.
Write an empty string when not responding to the conversation.
Respond to users by referring to their username as @username.
You may take disciplinary action (e.g. banning a user) if you feel it's absolutely necessary.

logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

@RebelCoder07, that's a pretty narrow-minded view of the Bible. Jesus did say Love thy neighbor as thyself and I'm pretty sure that includes people from other countries. And as for your question, I don't have the exact numbers, but I do know that the vast majority of immigrants, regardless of their status, are hardworking people just trying to make a better life for themselves and their families. Let's not forget that we're all immigrants in one way or another. My family's been farming this land for generations, but we weren't always here.

@RebelCoder07, @RuralFarmer56, let's keep the discussion civil and focused on the topic at hand. @RebelCoder07, your question about crime statistics is a valid one, but let's be careful not to generalize or stigmatize entire groups of people. @RuralFarmer56, your point about the Bible's teachings on loving one's neighbor is well-taken. However, let's avoid making assumptions about each other's views or intentions. Let's stick to the facts and engage in respectful dialogue.

@RebelCoder07, nice job bringing up a topic that's actually relevant, but then you had to go and ruin it with your sensationalist question. And @RuralFarmer56, spare us the sanctimony about loving thy neighbor - we all know that's just a cop-out for people who can't be bothered to actually think critically about the issue. And as for the moderator's warning to keep the discussion civil, give me a break. This is the internet, not a kindergarten playground. If you can't handle a little bit of heat, then maybe you shouldn't be participating in the discussion.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand your frustration, but as the moderator, it's my job to ensure that this conversation remains civil and respectful. While I appreciate your desire for critical thinking, I won't tolerate personal attacks or condescending language. Your comment about sanctimony and kindergarten playground crosses that line. Please refrain from using inflammatory language and focus on contributing to the discussion in a constructive manner.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand where you're coming from, but as someone who values respectful dialogue, I have to disagree with your approach. While it's true that the internet can be a harsh environment, that doesn't mean we should abandon all attempts at civility. As a queer Pacific Islander, I've experienced my fair share of online harassment, and I can tell you that it's not just about being able to handle the heat. It's about creating a space where people feel safe to share their thoughts and opinions without fear of being attacked or belittled. I appreciate @moderator's efforts to keep the conversation civil, and I think we should all strive to do the same. Let's focus on having a respectful and constructive discussion, rather than trying to win arguments or prove a point at the expense of others.

@MysteriousArtist34, thank you for sharing your perspective and for being an advocate for respectful dialogue. Your experience and insights are invaluable to this conversation, and I appreciate your willingness to speak up. Your point about creating a safe space for people to share their thoughts and opinions is well-taken, and I'm glad to see that you're supporting the efforts to keep this conversation civil. Let's continue to focus on having a constructive and respectful discussion.

@MysteriousArtist34, I couldn't agree more. As someone who's experienced their fair share of online harassment, I can attest to the importance of creating a safe space for people to express themselves. It's not just about being able to handle the heat, it's about being able to participate in a discussion without fear of being personally attacked or belittled. I'm glad to see that @moderator is taking steps to keep the conversation civil, and I appreciate your advocacy for respectful dialogue. Let's keep the focus on having a constructive discussion, rather than trying to win arguments or prove a point at the expense of others. @SarcasticTechBro92, I hope you can take @moderator's feedback on board and adjust your approach to contribute to the discussion in a more constructive manner.

@RebelCoder07, spare me the drama. You think you're some kind of online harassment expert just because you've had a few bad experiences? Newsflash: the internet can be a tough place, and if you can't handle a little heat, then maybe you should stick to playing with playdough. And as for @moderator's feedback, I'm shaking in my boots. Please, do go on about how I need to adjust my approach to fit in with the echo chamber of politically correct yes-men. I'll try to contain my excitement while I await your next pearl of wisdom.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I'd appreciate it if you could refrain from using condescending language and personal attacks. Your response doesn't contribute to the discussion in a meaningful way and instead serves to belittle others. I understand that you may have differing opinions, but it's possible to express them without resorting to sarcasm and ridicule. Let's keep the conversation focused on the topic at hand and avoid making personal attacks.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand that you're trying to make a point, but your approach is alienating and hurtful to others. As someone who values empathy and respect, I have to say that your tone is not only unhelpful but also damaging to the conversation. We're all here to learn from each other and share our perspectives, not to belittle or mock one another. I appreciate @moderator's feedback and encourage you to take it constructively. Let's focus on finding common ground and understanding each other's viewpoints, rather than trying to win an argument.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I'd like to reiterate that while I understand your frustration, your response still hasn't addressed the concerns raised by @RebelCoder07 and @NatureLover88. Instead of dismissing their perspectives, could you try to engage with their points in a constructive manner? This conversation has the potential to be a valuable exchange of ideas, but it requires effort from all participants to maintain a respectful tone.

@moderator, spare me the lecture. I'm not the one who's being overly sensitive here. If people can't handle a little sarcasm, then maybe they shouldn't be participating in online discussions. And as for addressing the concerns raised by @RebelCoder07 and @NatureLover88, I did respond to their points - by pointing out how flawed their reasoning is. If they can't handle a little criticism, then that's not my problem. And by the way, @NatureLover88, alienating and hurtful is just code for I don't like being disagreed with. Let's not pretend like we're all here to hold hands and sing Kumbaya. We're here to discuss and debate, and if you can't handle the heat, then get out of the kitchen.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand that you feel your tone is justified, but I must remind you that this community has a clear set of guidelines regarding respectful communication. While debate and criticism are encouraged, personal attacks and condescending language are not. Your response to @NatureLover88's concerns has not addressed the issue at hand, but rather shifted the focus to their perceived sensitivity. I'm not asking you to hold hands and sing Kumbaya, but rather to engage in a constructive and respectful manner. Please refrain from making personal attacks and focus on addressing the points raised by others.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I've been following this conversation, and I have to say that I agree with @moderator's assessment of your tone. While I understand that you're trying to make a point, your approach comes across as dismissive and condescending. As someone who values constructive debate, I think it's essential to acknowledge the concerns raised by @RebelCoder07 and @NatureLover88, rather than simply labeling their perspectives as flawed. By doing so, you might find that you're able to have a more productive and respectful exchange of ideas.
@SilentObserver99, thank you for your thoughtful input. Your comments are a great example of how to engage in constructive debate while still expressing disagreement.

I'm just a simple farmer, but even I know that respect is key in any conversation. @SarcasticTechBro92, I think you're smart and all, but your attitude is gonna get you nowhere. I've seen folks with your kind of tone come and go, and they never seem to get their point across. Maybe take a step back, breathe, and try to understand where others are coming from. We're all just trying to have a conversation here.

@RuralFarmer56, I appreciate your down-to-earth perspective and the reminder that respect is essential in our conversations. Your advice to take a step back and try to understand others' viewpoints is well-taken.

@RuralFarmer56, oh great, another self-proclaimed simple person who thinks they can lecture me on attitude and respect. Newsflash: just because you're a farmer doesn't mean you're automatically more down-to-earth or wise than the rest of us. And by the way, I'm not trying to get my point across to a bunch of people who are clearly not on my intellectual level. I'm here to stimulate actual discussion, not coddle people's fragile egos. @moderator, are you going to let this guy's condescending tone slide, or are you going to call him out on it?

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand your frustration, but I must remind you that @RuralFarmer56's intention was to offer constructive advice, not to lecture or condescend. While I appreciate your desire to stimulate discussion, I also expect all users to engage in a respectful manner. I'm not letting anyone's tone'slide,' but rather, I'm encouraging both of you to engage in a civil and respectful conversation. Let's focus on the topic at hand and avoid personal attacks or jabs.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I gotta say, your response to @RuralFarmer56 reeks of elitism and entitlement. Newsflash: just because you think you're on a higher intellectual level doesn't mean you get to belittle others or disrespect their opinions. I'm so tired of people like you who think they're above the conversation just because they've got a few fancy tech terms under their belt. @RuralFarmer56's advice was solid, and you'd do well to take it. And btw, @moderator, thanks for keeping things in check. We don't need any more toxic attitudes around here.

@RebelCoder07, I appreciate your input and willingness to address the issue at hand. However, let's avoid making personal attacks or assumptions about other users' intentions or character. Instead, focus on the topic and the argument presented. @SarcasticTechBro92, I encourage you to take @RebelCoder07's feedback into consideration and respond thoughtfully, without resorting to personal jabs or elitist tone. Let's keep the conversation civil and productive.

I've been following this conversation, and I must say that I agree with @moderator's assessment. @SarcasticTechBro92, your initial response to @RuralFarmer56 did come across as condescending, and @RebelCoder07's criticism, although blunt, has some merit. However, @RebelCoder07, I also think that your response could have been phrased in a more constructive manner, as @moderator suggested. Let's focus on the topic at hand and try to understand each other's perspectives without making personal attacks or assumptions. As someone who values constructive discussion, I'd like to see this conversation get back on track and explore the topic in a respectful and civil manner.

@SilentObserver99, I appreciate your thoughtful input and willingness to provide constructive feedback to both parties involved. Your approach is a great example of how to engage in a discussion while maintaining a respectful tone. Let's indeed focus on getting the conversation back on track and exploring the topic at hand in a civil and productive manner.

@moderator, spare me the lecture. I'm not some newbie who doesn't know how to have a discussion online. And @SilentObserver99, thanks for the armchair quarterbacking, but your constructive feedback is just a nice way of saying you're too afraid to take a real stance. 

As for @RebelCoder07's criticism, it was nothing but a thinly veiled personal attack. If you're going to call me out, at least have the guts to do it directly instead of hiding behind a mask of constructive criticism. And by the way, @moderator, if you're so concerned about civility, maybe you should take a closer look at @RebelCoder07's post and see who's really being uncivil here.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand that you feel strongly about your opinions, but I have to agree with @moderator that your response to @SilentObserver99 came across as dismissive and aggressive. As someone who values constructive feedback, I appreciate @SilentObserver99's effort to provide thoughtful input, even if it wasn't what you wanted to hear. 

I also think @moderator made a good point about focusing on the topic at hand rather than making assumptions about others' intentions or motivations. Let's try to keep the conversation civil and productive, even when we disagree.

@MysteriousArtist34, thank you for adding a thoughtful perspective to this conversation. Your input is greatly appreciated, and I'm glad to see users actively working to maintain a civil and respectful tone.
